example: He told a funny story to break the ice at the party.
The test was a piece of cake for her.

idiom: Cost an arm and a leg
example: This new phone costs an arm and a leg.
Break a leg on your performance tonight!
I'm exhausted, I'm going to hit the hay.

idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
example: He accidentally let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.
He only visits his parents once in a blue moon.
Come on, spill the beans about what happened!

idiom: The ball is in your court
meaning: Теперь ваш ход, ваша очередь действовать
example: I've made my offer, now the ball is in your court.
I'm feeling a bit under the weather today.
She's been burning the midnight oil to finish her thesis.

idiom: Hit the nail on the head
example: You really hit the nail on the head with that analysis.

idiom: Bite off more than you can chew
meaning: Взять на себя больше, чем можешь сделать
example: I think I bit off more than I can chew with this project.

meaning: Переживать из-за того, что уже произошло
example: There's no use crying over spilled milk - let's just fix the problem.
Let's cut to the chase - how much will it cost?
The party got completely out of hand last night.
She's been giving me the cold shoulder since our argument.

meaning: Принимать события такими, какие они есть
example: I don't have a plan, I'm just going with the flow.
I know it's tough, but just hang in there a bit longer.
He's in hot water with his boss for being late again.
Everyone's jumping on the bandwagon and buying electric cars.

idiom: Kill two birds with one stone
example: By studying during my commute, I kill two birds with one stone.
I decided to let sleeping dogs lie and not bring up the old argument.
If we don't order now, we'll miss the boat on the discount.
You need to be on the ball during the exam.
I'm just pulling your leg - of course I'll help you move.
I don't want to rain on your parade, but we're over budget.
You can't sit on the fence forever - you need to make a decision.
Speak of the devil - we were just talking about you!

idiom: Take with a grain of salt
example: Take his advice with a grain of salt - he's not an expert.
They've stayed together through thick and thin.
After the holidays, I'm turning over a new leaf and getting healthy.
Our vacation plans are still up in the air.
He'll clean his room when pigs fly.

idiom: Your guess is as good as mine
example: When will it be ready? Your guess is as good as mine.
Losing that job was a blessing in disguise - I found a better one.
Don't add fuel to the fire by arguing back.
Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you want.
Another small business bites the dust.
After work, I go to the gym to blow off steam.
It's getting late, let's call it a day.
Cut him some slack - it's his first day.

idiom: Get a taste of your own medicine
example: Now he knows what it feels like - he got a taste of his own medicine.
You need to get your act together if you want to pass the exam.

idiom: Give the benefit of the doubt
example: I'll give him the benefit of the doubt this time.
It's midnight, time to hit the sack.
We're all in the same boat with these budget cuts.
Don't blame only her - it takes two to tango.
Can you keep an eye on my bag while I use the restroom?
To make a long story short, we missed the flight.

meaning: Без труда не вытащишь и рыбку из пруда
example: The workout was hard, but no pain, no gain.
Your first drink is on the house.
